The origin of ketchup is believed to have originated in China in the 17th century, where it was made from fermented fish and spices. It then spread to Europe and eventually to the United States in the 19th century, where it was made with tomatoes.

Ketchup is believed to have originated in China in the 17th century as a fish-based sauce. It then spread to Europe and was adapted to include tomatoes, which were introduced to Europe from the Americas in the 16th century. The name "ketchup" is derived from the Chinese word "ke-tsiap," which was a pickled fish sauce.
